data.title: Frank Miller Mania #1: Daredevil #169 (His Name is Bullseye...) — WITS' END Podcast
data.meta_description: Frank Miller Mania begins here! Shah dives into Frank Miller’s comics—starting with the iconic Daredevil run. First up— Daredevil #169, featuring the return of the killer Bullseye!
data.text:
By: Shah (Twitter: @_shahcomics)

(NOTE: There are parts where the art just speaks for itself and I won’t do any talking!)

Thing, is— I called this thing “MANIA” because I’ve been on a Frank Miller binge lately. It’s mostly been a re-read of his superhero works. So… no SIN CITY for now! But I’ll be writing about some Miller comics.

I started the binge with RONIN, traveled to WOLVERINE and now…. I am re-reading Miller’s seminal run on DAREDEVIL. The original run spanned from 1979-1983 consecutively. BORN AGAIN and MAN WITHOUT FEAR came later.

Let’s get into it. Miller took over the writing and art duties on Daredevil with issue 168. That’s the issue that introduced Elektra, Matt’s old flame and globally recognized assassin.

(NOTE: Aside from Frank Miller Klaus Janson & Bill Sienkiewicz, no creator has really “understood” Elektra)

That’s not where the series hits its stride, though. It’s with #169 that Miller fires on all cylinders and becomes more ruthless in his storytelling.

Miller, Janson and colorist Glynis Wein re-introduce the killer who can’t miss in four of the most powerful pages in superhero comics. Yet, they’re unsung heroes. Let’s take a look!

Times Square during Christmas swallows a panicked Bullseye. He stands alone in the crowd like a child who lost their parents.

Panic sets in. The killer calms himself the only way he knows how.

This is the issue where Miller’s mastery of sequential art comes through. This is the sequence that’s been burned into my brain for years. Let me show you.

“By profession, he is a killer-for-hire,” the caption said. “And even among his fellow professionals, he is feared. In the next five seconds, you will discover why…”

Art moves on the page, making the reader hang off the edge of their seat. It’s brutal, merciless, gorgeously depicted. And the final kill is the gut-wrenching, the pull of a scarf is followed by the snap of a neck.

Goddamn, Frank.

Bullseye is an artist of murder. He’s missing one thing, though—his iconic costume. Miller and Janson show a genius three panel sequence of Bullseye entering a tailor’s shop. It’s not explicitly stated that Bullseye kills the man but, c’mon!
